title: 107_s2710
content: The Act titled "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit amount is based on the applicable percentage of qualified employee health insurance expenses paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The applicable percentage varies based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit amount is based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees, with varying percentages depending on the number of employees and their wages. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The credit percentage is calculated based on the number of employees and their wages, with a minimum percentage of 5% for employers with not more than 50 qualified employees earning an average annual rate of wages not exceeding $30,000. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 provides a credit for small business insurance expenses based on employee coverage limits. The maximum insurance expenses for a qualified employee are $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. Special rules and definitions apply, including determining employer eligibility based on the average number of employees in the preceding years. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business insurance expenses based on employee coverage limits. Employers must meet specific criteria, including providing health insurance coverage to at least 50% of qualified employees. The credit amount is determined based on the average number of employees in the preceding years. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for subsidized health plans. Amounts paid for health insurance coverage under a salary reduction arrangement are not considered for tax purposes. The term 'employee' excludes those eligible for subsidized health plans and includes individuals entitled to benefits under various healthcare programs or medical care programs. The term 'employee' excludes those eligible for subsidized health plans and includes individuals entitled to benefits under various healthcare programs or medical care programs. The definition of 'wages' for this purpose is determined by section 3121(a) without any dollar limitation. Rules similar to section 52 apply, and no double benefit deduction or credit is allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. The credit for employee health insurance expenses is part of the general business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment prohibits the carryback of the section 45G credit before January 1, 2003, for unused business credits. The amendment to section 45G allows for small business employee health insurance expenses to be deducted for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002, for coverage established post-enactment of the Act.
